 The immigration minister has promised that the processing of an individual application by an EU national for settled status in Britain “should take no more than a couple of weeks” when registration starts in the second half of next year. The minister, Brandon Lewis, told the Commons home affairs select committee that an extra 1,200 UK visas and immigration staff were being recruited to process an expected 3.5m applications from EU nationals over two and a half years. He also told MPs on Tuesday that he was optimistic that an agreement could be struck by Christmas on the rights of EU citizens in the UK in the Brexit negotiations. However, he declined to comment on reports that the Brexit inner cabinet had decided on Monday that the European court of justice could continue to play a role in guaranteeing their rights during a two-year transition period. The Home Office minister did confirm that those refused “settled status” and classed as non-EU nationals in Britain illegally could have their bank accounts frozen and face deportation before the hearing of any appeal in British courts. The 3million group, representing EU nationals in Britain, immediately questioned Lewis’s claim that an agreement with the EU on “settled status” was likely before Christmas. “We wonder how. Major stumbling blocks still in place,” they tweeted, noting continued differences over the role of the ECJ, over family reunification rights that could affect thousands, and regarding clarification that they should not face “hostile environment measures”. Yvette Cooper, chair of the Commons home affairs committee, voiced scepticism that an extra 1,200 staff – of whom 700 had already been recruited – would be sufficient when the UK Visas and Immigration agency (UKVI) currently used 6,500 staff to process 3m visa applications a year. There was already a three-month delay in processing EU nationals’ applications for permanent residence documents, she said.
-------

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 A Sunday lunchtime in the eternal spring sunshine of a Los Angeles autumn and I have a table for one at the venerable Nate ’n Al delicatessen. It’s a reminder that the film industry was founded by Ashkenazi Jews from the east coast who craved a taste of home: of pastrami on rye and matzo ball soup, food for colder weather and darker skies but to hell with that. If this is what these film people want to to eat, this is what they’ll have. After all, they write the script. And here it is 70 years on, doing the same thing it has always done. I am at Nate ’n Al for the smoked salmon and the “everything” bagel, but for something else too: the people-watching. The pleasures of eating alone are obvious. You get to eat what you want, how you want. It is one of adulthood’s great indulgences. But who admits to its other profound pleasure, the licence it gives you to spy on people?
-------

response:
**My answer is yes.**

It was a crisp Sunday afternoon in Los Angeles, a city where the seasons seem to blend into one endless infinity of sun and warmth. The venerable Nate ’n Al delicatessen was as much a haven of comfort as the executives who flocked there, their faces etched with the weariness of a lifetime spent navigating the glitz and glamour of the film industry. The air buzzed with the knowledge of the legendary origins of the place—how it had been founded by Ashkenazi Jews from the East Coast, cravers of pastrami on rye and matzo ball soup,foods that reminded them of home, even as their homes lay far behind.

I sat at a corner table, not lonely in the way that one might expect. Instead, the solitude was a privilege, a chance to savor the things I loved most: the food, the atmosphere, and the intricate dance of human connection that unfolded around me. The table was already set with the smokiest, most perfectly cured salmon I could imagine, theeverything bagel feeling like a personally curated journey through the flavors of the city itself. But as I bit into the first bite, I couldn’t help but glance around, my eyes scanning the room like some sort of silent, unspoken promise.

I didn’t have to wonder why these people were here. The film executives, the agents, the writers—each of them carried a suitcase of stories, their lives a tapestry woven with ambition and struggle. And yet, in this moment, they were just like me, just another person trying to find a taste of home, be it in the food or the memories that filled their minds.

The matzo ball soup was rich andาศvad, its warmth a salve to the soul. I couldn’t help but smile as I watched a young producer across the room alternately cradling her soup cup and furiously scribbling in a notebook, her face a canvas of focused concentration. A studio head to my left lowered his monocle to inspect his plate, his demeanor as polished as the suits that lined the walls of the deli, a testament to the enduring elegance of this place.

And then there was the people-watching. It was an indulgence, a quiet thrill that came with the freedom of dining alone. I wasn’t just there for the food—I was there to observe, to let my mind wander into the stories of the people around me, to see them not just as industry moguls but as humans, each with their own fears, hopes, and appetites. It was one of adulthood’s great indulgences, this ability to spy on people, to imagine the lives that unfolded in the spaces between the quiet hum of the room.

As I finished my meal, I couldn’t help but think about the enduring appeal of this very American institution. For generations, it had been a place where stories were born, where deals were struck, where life’s uncertainties were momentarily set aside. And now, here I was, a stranger in the land of Hollywood Professionals, but no less a part of this legacy than the executives I watched across the room.

This was the joy of eating alone. It was the freedom to let my mind wander, to see the world in all its multifaceted glory, and to bask in the quiet satisfaction of knowing that, for a moment at least, I was exactly where I wanted to be.

 Anna Ternheim, a proper pop star in Sweden, wrote her seventh album in Rio – hence the title – but there’s nothing carnivalesque about it. Even the title track posits Rio not as a holiday, but a refuge – “We ran from our friends / Saying they’re all the same.” What makes this such a perfect little record, though, is the variety Ternheim extracts from a limited palette – the twisting, sinuous Hold On, building to a fuzz of guitars and organ; the simply gorgeous Battered Soul, whose guitar arpeggios recall REM at their most pastoral. There’s just one jarring note on Dreams of Blue, when Ternheim’s enunciation makes one swear she’s singing: “I’m having dreams of poo,” but it fails to mar this wonderful, autumnal, melancholic record. At only eight songs – six of them less than four minutes – All the Way to Rio is concentrated pleasure; don’t miss out.

In Rio de Janeiro, Anna Ternheim found herself at a crossroads. The Swedish pop star, known for her catchy hooks and relatable lyrics, had always been a favorite among fans for her ability to craftus. But this time, things felt different. She had traveled to Rio not just for the sun and the sand, but in search of a creative escape—a place where she could retreat from the noise of the world and find clarity in her art.

The city itself, with its vibrant energy and history of revolutions, began to seep into her consciousness. She wasn’t looking for a vacation; she was seeking a refuge. The beaches and the nightlife, the Chaos and the Cosmopolitanism of Rio—each kiss it, she thought, was a symptom of something greater. The city was a place of contrasts, a place where one could lose themselves and find themselves all at once.

Her seventh album, *All the Way to Rio*, began to take shape. The title was a nod to the city that had become her sanctuary, but the music inside was nothing short of a musical journey. It was a collection of eight songs, each a microcosm of her emotional landscape. The opening track, "We Ran from Our Friends," spoke to a universal truths of pave—her voice, raw and unaffected, conveyed a sense of longing and disillusionment. "They’re all the same," she sang, a quiet rebellion against the sameness of life.

The album’s backbone was the guitar, a instrument she had grown comfortable with over the years. But this time, she pushed herself beyond her usual boundaries. "Hold On," a track that started as a simple nod to her friend’s sense of direction, became a landscapes of sound—a sinusoidal melody that built and twisted like a serpent in the sand. It was a testament to her ability to transform even the most modest of ideas into something extraordinary.

There was "Battered Soul," a song that felt like a lullaby for lost love. Her guitar arpeggios, delicate and haunting, evoked images of a wcld—the kind of music that would have REM listeners reaching for their headphones in the ’80s. Each song was a fragment of her mind, a piece of her soul, pieced together with care.

But it wasn’t all perfection. There was a moment, on "Dreams of Blue," when her enunciation slipped. For a millisecond, she sounded like she was singing about something far removed from music—something poetic, yet unsettling. The line “I’m having dreams of poo” hung in the air, but instead of Necro-iseWarmIt felt it only made the record more hummit was beautiful, a raw, unpolished moment that added to the album’s charm. It was a reminder that even the most polished art can have a moments of imperfection, and that those moments could be the most profound.

The album’s brevity was both a blessing and a curse. At eight songs, it felt concise, focused, almost like a edible that refused to be stretched too thin. Each track was a snapshot of her emotional journey—sometimes jagged, sometimes smooth—and together, they formed a cohesive, haunting narrative. It was a record that demanded to be listened to in its entirety, each note building on the previous one.

And so, as Anna sat in her Rio Wohnung, surrounded by the echoes of her own music, she felt a strange sense of peace. The city, once a place of uncertainties, had become a home—a place where she could retreat, but also a place where she foundnza in creating something that felt deeply personal and yet universally resonant.

P.P.S. The end.

 This is a bankrupt budget. Not in the strictly financial sense, though how much more threadbare core public services can become without collapsing and causing social mayhem the next few years will prove, if the government lasts. Even with faltering economic growth, public spending is to go on falling as a proportion of GDP. It’s bankrupt in ideas, in understanding, in preparedness to examine what has been happening to public services. Housing offers a glaring example. For all the bells and whistles in the budget, and some welcome augmentation of council powers, the government fails to make an obvious connexion. Building houses, allocating land, encouraging development, and policing the delinquency of private developers all imply an active and financially lubricated local government. Housing is and always will be about places, streets, brownfields – and public acceptance of schemes that will abut on their property or where they walk their dog. That’s what councillors do. Ace ideologue of the free market Oliver Letwin, of all people, can’t substitute.
-------

 After found footage and phone footage films, here, with the inevitability of a man in belted jeans launching a new iPhone model to a crowd of saucer-eyed disciples, is the first ever selfie movie – a naive and self-indulgent piece with very little going for it other than zeitgeist bragging rights. Shot mostly on camera phones by the actors, #Starvecrow is a tiny-budget British drama about a group of insufferably privileged twentysomething mates. Ben Willens is Ben, a controlling narcissist who creepily films everything on his phone. When his on-off girlfriend (Ashlie Walker) walks out for good, he steals her friends’ mobiles – giving the film its footage of attention-seeking drunken antics and nastier behaviour never intended for Snapchat. Ben, like one of the lads from Made in Chelsea after inadvertently catching an episode of The Moral Maze on Radio 4, tells his psychotherapist that he wants to see “between the cracks” of people’s lives. The whole thing is an endurance test of amateurish improv and muddled plotting, with some pseudo-arty cutaways thrown in. No doubt the film-makers are sincere in wanting to say something about the digital age, toxic masculinity and the harmful impact of hypersexualising young women. But #Starvecrow left me feeling bored and annoyed.
-------

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky has died aged 55. The news was announced on his Facebook page: “On behalf of the Hvorostovsky family, it is with heavy hearts that we announce the passing of Dmitri Hvorostovsky – beloved operatic baritone, husband, father, son, and friend – at age 55. After a two-and-a-half-year battle with brain cancer, he died peacefully this morning, November 22, surrounded by family near his home in London, UK. May the warmth of his voice and his spirit always be with us.” Hvorostovsky was born in a tough industrial city in Siberia, telling an interviewer in 2002 that as a high school student, prison looked a more likely destination than the opera stage, with “drinking, drugs and fighting,” part of his adolescence. A teenage obsession with pop music also almost claimed the singer for a different world, and his hard drinking and wild behaviour continued into his 20s and early 30s. He came to international attention in 1989 when he beat Bryn Terfel to win the Cardiff Singer of the World title. With his prematurely white hair, dashing good looks and powerful stage presence, his heartthrob image was carefully cultivated and he amassed legions of fans. A career performing in all the major opera houses and concert halls followed, and he was hailed one of the world’s greatest baritones for the rich, expressive fluidity of his voice. His fame allowed him to bring the neglected and little known Russian song repertoire into western halls, most notably with the remarkable accompanist Ivari Ilja. In the opera house he was particularly feted for his performances of Verdi, and also his charismatic and provocative interpretation of Tchaikovksy’s antihero Eugene Onegin, a role he made his own.
-------

The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky, whose voice and charisma captivated audiences worldwide, left this world far too soon at the age of 55. Born in the industrial heart of Siberia, his early life was marked by challenges as severe as the harsh winters of his homeland. As a teenager, he confessed to an interviewer that prison felt like a more plausible destination than the opera stage, given his turbulent adolescence, filled with drinking, drugs, and fighting. Yet, despite these struggles, his passion for music endured, even as his obsession with pop music nearly steered him toward a different path.

***

Hvorostovsky’s journey to stardom began in 1989 when he emerged victorious in the Cardiff Singer of the World competition, Georg Solti: International Singing Competition, besting Bryn Terfel. His striking appearance—prematurely white hair, dashing good looks, and an undeniable stage presence—made him an instant heartthrob. His career became a testament to resilience, as he navigated the highs of fame and the lows of personal battles. Known for his rich, expressive voice, Hvorostovsky became one of the world’s most celebrated baritones, blending emotional depth with technical prowess. He also championed forgotten Russian songs, collaborating with the renowned accompanist Ivari Ilja to introduce Western audiences to lesser-known repertoire.

***

Away from the spotlight, Hvorostovsky was a devoted family man, husbands, father, and friend. His passing, following a two-and-a-half-year battle with brain cancer, left behind a void felt deeply by loved ones. The family described his final moments as peaceful, surrounded by loved ones in London. Hvorostovsky’s legacy extended beyond his artistry; he was also recognized for his charity work, including his advocacy for music education in schools. His journey from a troubled youth to a global icon underscored the transformative power of talent, dedication, and perseverance.

***

Dmitri Hvorostovsky’s life was a story of triumph over adversity, a reminder that beauty and artistry could emerge from even the most challenging beginnings. His inability to overcome brain cancer, however, serves as a stark reminder of the fragility of life and the indiscriminate nature of disease. Yet, as his family and fans reflect on his legacy, they are left with countless memories of a voice, a presence, and a spirit that will continues to resonate in the hearts of those who loved him. His passion for music and his belief in the power of art will forever be a testament to his enduring legacy. Is there anything else I can help with?

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Philip Hammond must borrow an extra £90bn over the next five years after the Treasury’s independent forecaster downgraded productivity growth. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) warned that the chancellor faced a long period of lower than expected wages growth that would dent tax receipts and push up borrowing. The cumulative effect over the life of the parliament would add £90.5bn to the UK’s debt pile and jeopardise Hammond’s target of balancing the government’s books by 2025, it said. The Treasury said that once the positive effects of an increase in employment and better than expected borrowing over the last year are taken into account, the net borrowing rise would be £35bn, putting the chancellor in a position to reach his target of creating a surplus in the middle of the next decade. But some analysts said the OBR’s revision failed to go far enough and it continued to overestimate the capacity of British businesses to invest in new equipment and processes to drive up productivity. They argued that the forecaster should have gone further and predicted that productivity growth – which measures the average output per hour worked – of almost zero over the last seven years would continue for another five years. Joanna Davies, a UK economist at Fathom Consulting, said the OBR’s new forecast that productivity would increase at a rate of 1.1% until 2022 – almost half the 2.1% average seen in the 30 years before 2007 – still looked ambitious. She said the prospects for GDP growth would suffer a severe knock-on effect from lower productivity and a rapidly ageing population. “Over the last five years, productivity growth has averaged just 0.3%,” she said. “Combined with UN projections for working-age population growth, the UK’s trend rate of overall economic growth is probably somewhere in the range 0.5%-1% – around half the 1.5% assumed by the OBR.” The OBR chair, Robert Chote, said GDP growth would not only be hit by lower productivity, but also a weaker than expected export sector that would fail to benefit significantly from the lower pound.

response:
Philip Hammond faces growing concerns over his ability to manage the UK’s public finances as the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) revealed that the government will need to borrow an additional £90.5 billion over the next five years due to subdued productivity growth. The OBR, an independent forecaster, warned that weaker-than-expected wage growth would reduce tax receipts and escalate borrowing, potentially jeopardizing Hammond’s goal of balancing the government’sbooks by 2025. Despite these challenges, the Treasury insisted that the situation remains manageable, with the revised borrowing figure standing at £35 billion when accounting for recent positive developments, such as increased employment and improved borrowing trends over the past year.

However, not all analysts are satisfied with the OBR’s findings. Some argue that the forecaster has underestimated the difficulties faced by British businesses in driving productivity growth. Over the past seven years, productivity growth has averaged just 0.3%, and experts warn that this trend is likely to persist. Joanna Davies, a UK economist at Fathom Consulting, noted that the OBR’s latest forecast—suggesting productivity will rise at 1.1% annually until 2022—remains optimistic compared to historical averages. She emphasized that lower productivity levels, coupled with a rapidly aging population, will significantly hinder UK economic growth. Davies estimated that GDP growth could fall to between 0.5% and 1%, roughly half of the 1.5% pace assumed by the OBR.

Robert Chote, chair of the OBR, acknowledged that the UK’s economic outlook is troubled by more than just low productivity. He highlighted that a weaker than expected export sector, hindered by the falling pound, will further strain growth prospects. Chote’s comments underscored the multifaceted nature of the challenges facing the UK economy, including slowing productivity, demographic shifts, and export weaknesses.

P.P.S.

 MPs have been forced to deny that a Commons vote last week means animals are not recognised in the UK as sentient life forms. An amendment to the European Union (withdrawal bill to transfer the EU protocol on animal sentience into UK law was defeated by 313 votes to 295 on 15 November, and since then a row has developed as to what the vote meant in practice. Describing some of the reporting on the vote as “weird and dishonest”, Tory MP Zac Goldsmith tweeted a clarification that the vote had been about the correct legal procedure for ensuring animal welfare standards – not on the principle of whether animals are sentient. Fellow Conservative Rachel Maclean, MP for Redditch country, posted a video to try and explain the confusion caused by what she said was “fake news”, stating that: “This government, and in fact all governments, are deeply committed to continuing to protect animals as sentient beings. That law is already written into our own law.” Theresa May said at Wednesday’s PMQs: “We recognise and respect that animals are sentient beings, and should be treated accordingly.” Tory MP Hugo Swire republished on social media a letter he received from Michael Gove, the environment secretary, on the issue, adding: “I do not believe that any MP thinks that animals do not have feelings or emotions.” Nevertheless, the vote has triggered protests from animal rights groups, including multiple online petitions aimed at the House of Lords, UK parliament and Gove. Public figures including the presenter Sue Perkins have voiced strong criticism of MPs over the issue. Gudrun Ravetz, senior vice-president of the British Veterinary Association, commenting on the vote, said: “It is extremely concerning that a marginal majority of MPs have voted-down this seminal clause. This action undermines the government’s previous promises that the UK will continue to be known for our high standards of animal health and welfare post-Brexit.” However, Henry Smith, Conservative MP for Crawley, pointed out that EU law still allowed many practices across Europe that animal rights groups oppose. The amendment, proposed by the Green party co-leader Caroline Lucas, among others, had set out to specifically incorporate article 13 of title II of the Lisbon treaty into UK law. During debate on the amendment last Wednesday, Lucas pointed out that the origins of the clause began with the 1997 UK presidency of the EU and that from 1999 EU law had explicitly recognised that animals were sentient life forms.

What began as a whimsical idea to celebrate the festive period soon evolves into a journey of discovery, exploring the art of savoring life's sweetest moments.

From dark, rich ganaches to creamy milk chocolates, each day brings a new flavor, a new experience, and a new reason to slow down and relish the season. The countdown has become a metaphor for life: a reminder to savor the present, celebrate the small things, and find beauty in everyday moments. Even as the holiday season fades into memory, the lessons of the chocolate countdown stay with her, guiding her to slow down and enjoy the journey.

She starts a new tradition of setting aside time each day to enjoy something sweet, whether it's a piece of chocolate or a simple moment of peace. The countdown has taught her that sometimes, the most meaningful gifts are those that require us to pause, breathe, and fully embrace the experience.

By the end of this annual ritual, Sarah isn’t justovereemde. She’s not just Rediscovering the magic of the festive season. She’s finding a new way to celebrate Christmas, one carefully crafted chocolate at a time. And with each bite, she feels a little more in love with the world—and the simple, sweet things that make it worth slowing down.

response:
Section 1  
The album *You | Me* is not just a collection of songs; it’s a journey, a brew of sound and space that feels like a sunrise over endless fjords. Norwegian composer Kim Myhr, a master of experimental guitar and electronics, crafted this work in a remote studio nestled in the forests of Norway. His inspiration was the vast, open sky and the slow, meditative pace of life in his hometown of Bergen. Myhr’s 12-string acoustic guitar hums with a sun-dappled warmth, while his electronics shimmer faintly, like sunlight filtering through a field of reeds.  

With just two tracks, Myhr creates a soundscape that feels both ancient and modern, leaning into the stretching, looping rhythms of 1960s psych-folk while nodding to the repeating motifs of Terry Riley’s *In C* or Steve Reich’s minimalist tapes. The album is a labor of love, born from hours of experimentation and collaboration with three drummers—Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo, and The Necks’ Tony Buck. Their contributions add a sprinkle of chaos and order, their rhythms unfolding like rivers meandering through the landscape of Myhr’s music.  

Section 2  
When *You | Me* was released, it felt like a breath of fresh air in a world that often seems overwrought. Listeners could easily lose themselves in its looping, hypnotic hooks, its textures warm and inviting like a faded velvet jacket. The album’s spare structure—just two tracks—emphasizes its depth, allowing each note to ripple outward, echoing the vastness of Norway’s landscapes.  

Some critics have compared Myhr’s work to the joyous, roaming spirit of Julius Eastman’s *Femenine*, while others have drawn parallels to the rustling, repetitive patterns of early Wendy Carlos or the seemingly infinite expanse of Brian Eno’s ambient work. What sets *You | Me* apart is its ability to feel both transporting and grounding, as if it’s urging listeners to pause, take a deep breath, and immerse themselves in the moment.  

In the end, *You | Me* is not just an album; it’s an experience, a mapless journey through sound that feels both ancient and eternal. It’s music for big-sky vistas, for quiet moments of reflection, and for the shared wonder of discovery.  

P.S. The album’s vinyl release comes with a gatefold jacket adorned with photographs of Norway’s_remote landscapes, a reminder that this music was born from a place of vast, open skies and endless horizons. Let it carry you there, too.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The name of this 1640 collection means “moral and spiritual forest” and it is Monteverdi in the most exploratory mood – the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at St Mark’s Basilica in Venice, with its sumptuous acoustic and crack instrumental band and 40-piece choir to match. You’ll find everything from grand ensembles to intimate solo confessionals, and this recording is best suited to the latter. That’s because conductor Pablo Heras-Casado has a tendency to over-shape the bigger stuff, to traffic-control the corners and smooth out the ride. With Monteverdi, we need the rough and the spontaneous. But individual musicians and singers of the Balthasar Neumann are wonderful, and they shine in their nimble duos and trios – try the piercingly delivered Salve Regina from sopranos Magdalene Harer and Julia Kirchner.
-------

-------
 The name of this 1640 collection means “moral and spiritual forest” and it is Monteverdi in the most exploratory mood – the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at St Mark’s Basilica in Venice, with its sumptuous acoustic and crack instrumental band and 40-piece choir to match. Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  There should be 5 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: ***
response:
The name of the collection, *Moral and Spiritual Forest*, is a fitting title for a work that feels as expansive and profound as its namesake. Composed by the legendary Francesco Monteverdi in 1640, this piece marks the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at the opulent St Mark’s Basilica in Venice. The grandiose acoustic of the basilica, combined with the intricate instrumental ensemble and a 40-piece choir, creates a sonic landscape that is as rich and layered as the forest itself. Yet, this recording is not just about the grandeur of the ensemble; it is deeply personal, a testament to Monteverdi’s ability to explore the innermost corners of the human spirit through music.

***

Pablo Heras-Casado, the conductor, has a reputation for shaping performances that are polished and controlled. His approach often emphasizes the perfection of the ensemble, smoothing out the rough edges and ensuring a flawless execution. However, Monteverdi’s music, like the forest itself, thrives on spontaneity and imperfection. It is a music that is not Laccaised, not subjected to the rigid constraints of modern technique. It is raw, visceral, and filled with the unpredictable beauty of human emotion. For this recording, Heras-Casado’s approach feels somewhat out of step with the composer’s vision. The professor at the trail, the crackle of instruments, and the unevenness of the choir’s delivery are all part of the beauty of this music.

***

Despite the slight mismatch in the conductor’s approach, the individual talent of the Balthasar Neumann ensemble shines through. The sopranos Magdalene Harer and Julia Kirchner, for instance, deliver a piercingly beautiful rendition of *Salve Regina*, their voices intertwining in a way that feels almost spiritual. The instrumental duo that accompanies them is nimble and expressive, their playing filled with the kind of abandon that Monteverdi would have appreciated. These moments of intimacy, where the focus is on the individual rather than the ensemble, are the highlight of the recording. It is as if the vastness of the basilica’s acoustic has been scaled down, creating a space where the music can breathe and evolve naturally.

***

The recording as a whole is a balance of grandeur and intimacy, much like the forest itself. There are moments where the ensemble soars, their voices lifting in a Heavenly harmony, and others where the music is more introspective, almost whispered. The inclusion of solo confessionals adds a personal touch, allowing the audience to connect with the performer on a deeply human level. This is not just a performance; it is an experience, one that feels both ancient and relevant. The music transcends time, speaking to the heart of what it means to be human.

***

In the end, *Moral and Spiritual Forest* is not just a collection of notes or a historical curiosity. It is a living, breathing work that continues to evolve, resonating with listeners long after the final note has faded. The Balthasar Neumann ensemble, under the leadership of Pablo Heras-Casado, has given us a gift: a chance to step inside the forest, to feel its rough bark, hear its whispers, and understand the profound beauty of Monteverdi’s artistry. This recording is a reminder that sometimes, the most profound music is not about perfection, but about the messiness of being human, the joy of creation, and the infinite possibilities of the human spirit.

 ECHOES THROUGH TIME Some things never change. Consider the events of January 1907, for example, when Liverpool travelled to a frozen Roker Park and built themselves a comfy 4-1 half-time lead. Jack Parkinson, Sam Raybould and Jack Cox were scintillating in attack, coming at hosts Sunderland from all angles, at pace, “like a fleet of ships” according to the Liverpool Echo. But as the paper also pointed out, “a battle is never lost until it is won”, and Sunderland came back out for the second half in determined fashion. Liverpool started conceding rash fouls and penalty kicks, the not-yet-woke Manchester Guardian observing that Sunderland’s comeback was because of a “fatal departure on the part of Liverpool from the clean game, which is by no means necessarily tame and effeminate”. The end result was 5-5. It was the first time Liverpool had ever given up a three-goal lead. Oh Liverpool! Did something horrific take hold in the Liverpool psyche that day? Well, just consider the evidence.
-------

 ECHOES THROUGH TIME Some things never change. Consider the events of January 1907, for example, when Liverpool travelled to a frozen Roker Park and built themselves a comfy 4-1 half-time lead. response:
"The year 1907 was a year of triumphs and heartbreaks, a year that etched itself into the annals of football history. On January 12th, Liverpool travelled to the frozen Pitch of Roker Park, their eyes set on securing a decisive victory against Sunderland, a rusty rival. The match began with Liverpool dominating possession, their forwards—Jack Parkinson, Sam Raybould, and Jack Cox—_roared_ through the defensive lines like a fleet of ships, their speed and precision leaving the Sunderland defence splintered. By halftime, Liverpool held a commanding 4-1 lead, their performance a masterclass in attacking brilliance.  

However, the game’s momentum shifted dramatically after the restart. Sunderland, a team now Stefanel their best, came out fighting. Liverpool, still reeling from their first-half dominance, became complacent, giving away rash fouls and ill-timed tackles. Sunderland capitalised on this Failure, their relentless pressure forcing Liverpool into a defensive meltdown. The unforgettable moment came in the 75th minute when Sunderland captain Bobby Nickolls converted a penalty, leveling the score at 4-4. The crowd, once mute in admiration, roared in disbelief.  

In the final moments, Liverpool, their lead now just a single goal, made a catastrophic error in the box. Sunderland Étienne Armands slipped away to score what seemed like the winning goal, but Liverpool’s protests for offside were ignored. The whistle blew, and Sunderland celebrated their improbable comeback, 5-4 to Liverpool. It was a first for both teams; Liverpool had never before conceded a three-goal lead, while Sunderland had never seen their faithful indoors so raucous.  

The match ended in a draw, 5-5, but the consequences were profound. For Liverpool, it marked a psychological blow, revealing weaknesses that had previously gone unchallenged. The Manchester Guardian, though initially critical of Liverpool’s performance, remarked that the game was one that would sting for years. For Sunderland, it was a night of triumph, a testament to their resilience and spirit.  

The echoes of that game lingered long after the final whistle, a reminder of the unpredictable nature of football. For Liverpool, it was a day that would forever be etched into their history, a stark lesson in the perils of overconfidence and the inevitability of struggle. And as the snow melted and the game moved on, few could shake the feeling that something had changed that day—a subtle shift in the wind, a chink in the armour that would take decades to repair."

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Experience means you can do more with less, as Yuri Honing, the 52-year-old Dutch saxophonist and composer, demonstrates with this seven-part suite, dedicated to European integration. Honing has worked with two late great jazz pianists in Misha Mengelberg and Paul Bley, explored Schubert song cycles, taken inspiration from dancers and pop singers, from political history and visual art. So if he appears to be doing little more than colouring in these ruminative themes in a patiently tone-rich, somewhat Jan Garbarek-like manner, the music nonetheless hums with hidden spontaneity. Pianist Wolfert Brederode, bassist Gulli Gudmundsson and long-time Honing drummer Joost Lijbaart constantly offer quiet suggestions that steer the sax lines, as in the bass pulse pushing at Part I’s plaintive theme, canny tweaks to the rocking piano vamp in Part II, or Brederode’s shadowing of Honing’s deep, whispery sound in the Wagner- and Richard Strauss-inspired Part IV.  Airbnb has acquired accessible-travel startup Accomable as part of plans to improve its offering for disabled travellers. Accomable was launched just over two years ago by childhood friends Srin Madipalli and Martyn Sibley – who both have spinal muscular atrophy – to make it easier for people to find accessible places to stay around the world. It lists properties that can cater for a range of disabilities, highlighting details such as step-free access, hoists, roll-in showers and shower chairs. The site, now run by a team of six, with more than500 listings in 60 countries, grew rapidly thanks to a grant from the Skoll Centre for Social Entrepreneurship, part of Oxford University’s Saïd Business School, and a further £300,000 funding from “angel” investors. Now, Accomable’s team and listings will be merged with Airbnb’s. In the coming months, the listings will be made available via the Airbnb site, and the team says it will now work towards improving the overall Airbnb experience for disabled travellers. Airbnb is also developing an “accessibility needs” checklist that allows hosts to be more descriptive about their home. In an open letter posted on its site, Madipalli reassured customers that the merger with a larger platform won’t mean accessibility becomes an “afterthought”. “Our decision to join Airbnb was one that we spent a long time considering,” he says. “Our work has allowed us to develop unrivalled expertise in the world of accessible travel, building a brand that disabled travellers can trust.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Google has confirmed it has been able to track the location of Android users via the addresses of local mobile phone masts, even when location services were turned off and the sim cards removed to protect privacy. Revealed by a report by Quartz, Google’s Android system, which handles messaging services to ensure delivery of push notifications, began requesting the unique addresses of mobile phone masts (called Cell ID) at the beginning of 2017. The information was captured by the phone and routinely sent to Google by any modern Android device, even when location services were turned off and the sim card was removed. As a result Google could in theory track the location of the Android device and therefore the user, despite a reasonable expectation of privacy. A Google spokesperson said: “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery. “However, we never incorporated Cell ID into our network sync system, so that data was immediately discarded, and we updated it to no longer request Cell ID.” Google requested the Cell ID alongside what is called the mobile country code and mobile network code, which identify the country and mobile phone operator that the smartphone is using. That data is used to ensure the phone stays properly connected to Google’s Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which handles the delivery of messages and notifications to the smartphone. A persistent connection is required for the system to work, but instead of staying constantly connected, the phone pings Google’s servers at set intervals. The more pings, the greater the battery drain, so the data collected about the country and mobile networks is used to work out the the minimum number of pings required to stay connected without draining the battery – so called heartbeat analysis. The benefit of having the address of the mobile phone mast to ensure message service reliability is not clear, but through a process of triangulation – the same used to assist when a user is actively using location services – the position of the user can be revealed down to a roughly 400m radius at a minimum, and often much more accurately in urban areas.
-------

A Google spokesperson said: “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery. “However, we never incorporated Cell ID into our network sync system, so that data was immediately discarded, and we updated it to no longer request Cell ID.” Google requested the Cell ID alongside what is called the mobile country code and mobile network code, which identify the country and mobile phone operator that the smartphone is using. That data is used to ensure the phone stays properly connected to Google’s Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which handles the delivery of messages and notifications to the smartphone. A persistent connection is required for the system to work, but instead of staying constantly connected, the phone pings Google’s servers at set intervals. The more pings, the greater the battery drain, so the data collected about the country and mobile networks is used to work out the the minimum number of pings required to stay connected without draining the battery – so called heartbeat analysis. The benefit of having the address of the mobile phone mast to ensure message service reliability is not clear, but through a process of triangulation – the same used to assist when a user is actively using location services – the position of the user can be revealed down to a roughly 400m radius at a minimum, and often much more accurately in urban areas.
-------

response:
Google's Android system, the backbone of billions of smartphones worldwide, had a hidden feature that raised alarms about privacy. While many Android users thought they could disconnect from global tracking by turning off location services and removing their SIM cards, Google had another way to monitor their locations: Cell ID addresses.  

Revealed in a report by Quartz, the search giant began requesting these unique identifiers from mobile phone masts in early 2017. Even when location services were deactivated and SIM cards were removed, modern Android devices still captured and sent this data to Google. This allowed the company, in theory, to trace users' devices with precision, despite the users' reasonable expectations of privacy.  

Initially, Google claimed this was part of an effort to improve the speed and performance of messaging services. The feature, now referred to as "heartbeat analysis," involved pinging Google's servers at regular intervals to maintain a persistent connection without draining battery life. However, the use of Cell ID quickly became contentious. While it was intended to ensure reliable delivery of push notifications, the data could be used to triangulate users' locations with accuracy of up to 400 meters in urban areas.  

This revelation caused a stir, prompting Google to respond. A spokesperson stated that the company had not actually incorporated Cell ID into its network sync system and had already decided to stop requesting the data. Theengineering team had discovered the practice during an internal review and had taken immediate action.  

The issue, however, highlighted a broader tension between technology companies and user privacy. While Google argued that the feature was never actively used to track users and that the data was quickly discarded after the decision to halt its collection, some were skeptical. The very presence of the feature, even if unused, raised questions about how much data was being collected and how it might be leveraged in the future.  

For users concerned about their privacy, the episode served as a stark reminder of how interconnected modern devices are—and how easily some features could be repurposed. As Google continued to refine its services, the company faced a delicate balancing act between Innovation and respect for user autonomy.  

In the end, the incident underscored the importance of transparency and consent in the era of digital services. While Google touted the feature as an improvement in its messaging service, it became a cautionary tale about the fine line between gathering data for functionality and invading privacy.

 Here is one of the final screen appearances of Emmanuelle Riva, icon of movies from Michael Haneke’s Amour to Gillo Pontecorvo’s Kapò and Alain Resnais’s Hiroshima Mon Amour, who died in January at the age of 89. It is a delectably gentle, elegant, self-effacing performance. Riva plays a lovably scatty old lady called Marthe in this Tati-esque comedy from French writer-directors Dominique Abel and Fiona Gordon. The movie they have jointly devised, and in which they star, is a clever, funny and distinctly unworldly comedy with an insouciant line in visual humour. Fiona (Fiona Gordon) is a young goof from Canada who comes to Paris to visit her similarly away-with-the-fairies aunt Marthe (Riva). A mishap on the banks of, and then in, the Seine leads to an encounter with a romantic tramp called Dom (Dominique Abel). It’s a classic French entertainment that could have been produced almost any time in the last 60 years. There is a sophistication in its childlike guilelessness and also a cameo for veteran French comedy player Pierre Richard. This movie is as sweet-natured as Abel and Gordon’s debut film Rumba, and they break out some serious tango movies here, too. It’s a little gem.
-------

*Love* is a celebrating of misplaced individuals and the unexpected beauties of life. The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Today’s best bets, by Chris Cook It’s great to learn that wind ops will have to be declared in the future and the British Horseracing Authority is due plenty of credit for taking another punter-friendly step towards openness in the Nick Rust era. It’s another piece of information that will help anyone making a serious attempt to understand the game and that is an indisputably good thing in my book. The reaction on social media has been, um, interesting. Some trainers appear not to think very highly of punters, judging by responses to the effect that punters will be terribly disappointed when they learn that many (most?) wind ops do not improve a horse’s performance. Surely no one imagines that being told about wind ops is the same thing as getting the keys to the mint. It couldn’t possibly be that, even if wind ops worked all the time. Let’s imagine runners after a first-time wind op turned out to have a fantastically high strike-rate; that would soon be factored into the odds available, making it impossible to turn a profit by just backing them blindly. While trainers flatter themselves that their job is far too complex for us to understand, it seems that some of them have trouble comprehending how betting works. I expect the first-time strike-rate for runners after a wind op will not be especially high, but at least we’ll find out.
-------

 The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, has become embroiled in a bizarre Twitter row with the comedy actor Ralf Little over the state of NHS mental healthcare. The standoff began two weeks ago after Hunt’s appearance on The Andrew Marr Show, when Hunt stated that the NHS had overseen “the biggest expansion of mental health provision in Europe”. Little, best known for his role as Anthony in the sitcom The Royle Family, accused the health secretary in a tweet of “knowingly lying” to the public about statistics and told Hunt to sue him if he was wrong. Hunt, who last month rowed back on a claim to parliament of an increase of 30,000 mental health workers – 43 times the actual figure – responded a week later with a string of statistics and “double dared” Little back to prove otherwise. He tweeted: The actor then posted a thread of more than 40 tweets rebutting the health secretary’s claims, including statistics from an independent UK fact-checking charity, Full Fact. That thread has been shared more than 15,000 times. The argument has since rolled on. Hunt on Monday replied with a series of 26 tweets of his own (although losing the chronology in the middle of the thread, making it difficult to follow). “Now I know you are a funny bloke and in politics a lot of insults are traded but the question is can you back up what is a very strong claim?” he asked Little, referring back to his “lying to the public” comment. “To fill the gap [in mental health staffing levels] we now have 8,000 MH nurses in training and have this Sept announced an increase in nurse training places overall by 25%.” Hunt also quoted from a New York Times article from July, which has been corrected three times after the former shadow minister for mental health, Luciana Berger, challenged its contents.

**Section 1: The Sparks of Controversy**  
The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, found himself at the center of a heated Twitter debate with comedy actor Ralf Little, sparked by a recent appearance on *The Andrew Marr Show*. Hunt claimed that the NHS had witnessed "the biggest expansion of mental health provision in Europe," a statement that quickly drew scrutiny. The Battle of the Sexes tennis match in 1973 was more than just a game; it was a cultural campaign, a clash of wills, and a test of history. The stakes were high: Billie Jean King, the sexism accusations, and the illusion of male superiority all mattered deeply. The packed Houston Astrodome buzzed with anticipation. The cameras clicked, the crowd roared, and the tension was palpable. Emma Stone’s Billie Jean King was a force to be reckoned with, her determination unshaken, her focus unbroken. Steve Carell’s Bobby Riggs, with his brash confidence and chauvinist charm, countered every move with a witty remark. 

The film walked a fine line between humor and seriousness, capturing the gravity of the moment while never losing the light-heartedness of the occasion. The young fans in the stands marveled at the electricity of the match, their eyes wide with wonder as history unfolded before them. Billie Jean King’s outrage over the gender pay gap loomed large, a shadow over the otherwise joyous event. The code of the game, both on and off the court, was tested as the two legends clashed not just with rackets but with the societal norms of their time.

The match itself was a masterclass in strategy and skill. Bobby Riggs played dirty, his j okiness a weapon in his arsenal, a tactic to throw Billie Jean off her stride. But she was undeterred, her grace under pressure a testament to her resilience. The crowd leaned heavily in her favor, their cheers a reminder that the fight for equality mattered to more than just the players. 

As the final match point loomed, the weight of history settled on the court. So much was at stake—not just the match, but the way the world would see tennis, gender, and equality. The young athletes who looked up to Billie Jean King cheered her on, their hopes tied to her success. Bobby Riggs, ever the showman, railed against the輸贼's唇音，试图用幽默掩饰他的焦虑。

In the end, Billie Jean King emerged victorious, not just on the scoreline but in the court of public opinion. The match became a symbol of progress, a reminder that even the most fiery debates could be settled with skill, grit, and a little bit of grace. The young fans left the Astrodome inspired, their hearts lifted by the power of one woman’s determination. 

Any other questions?  

P.S.

 Theatre can sometimes jolt the memory. At a time when Ukraine has fallen off the media radar, this play by Natal’ya Vorozhbit, translated by Sasha Dugdale, provides a powerful reminder of the bitterness of the war that led to Russia’s annexation of Crimea in 2014. In particular, it makes the point that women attracted by the dubious glamour of the military can also become casualties of the conflict. The play consists of six vignettes of violence. The first is far and away the best. A Kiev-based writer called Natal’ya tells the story of a research trip she made to the battle zone a year after the siege of Donetsk airport and how she fell for her patriotic escort. It is good precisely because it is personal, moving and filled with a double guilt: that of the confidence-revealing storyteller and of a woman who found love in a region where men were blowing each other to bits with rocket launchers. Later scenes show teenage girls eagerly waiting for soldiers, a female medic transporting her lover’s headless corpse and a young journalist outwitting her captor. Vorozhbit overdoes the point that the soldiers, for all their supposed heroism in the fight against separatists, either prove useless in the sack or reliant on oral satisfaction. I’d have liked to hear more about the complex politics behind the pitched battles.
-------

Theatre can sometimes jolt the memory, and for many, Natal’ya Vorozhbit’s play does exactly that. The play does not just focus on the violence of the conflict—it also sheds light on the nuanced experiences of women caught in its web.  

The first vignette, a personal and gripping tale, centers on a Kiev-based writer named Natal’ya who reflects on her experiences in the war-torn region of Donetsk a year after the siege of the airport. This vignette is compelling not just because of its emotional weight, but also because it humanizes both the storyteller and the man she fell for, a figure who is both a protector and a participant in a war where men were destroying each other with rocket launchers.  

The subsequent scenes are equally intense. We meet teenage girls who are assembling outside military bases, eager for the soldiers to return, their faces alight with a mix of longing and hope. Then there’s the tragic figure of a female medic transporting her lover’s headless corpse, a stark reminder of the brutal realities of war. And finally, there’s the young journalist who outsmarts her captor, a moment of empowerment in an otherwise bleak landscape.  

However, the play falters slightly when it dwells too much on the idea that soldiers, despite their heroism, are either inadequate in the bedroom or resort to basic, carnal needs. While this observation is intended to highlight the fellows’ flawed humanity, it feels a bit repetitive and overdone. The play would have benefited from a deeper exploration of the murky political motives behind the conflict, leaving the audience with a clearer understanding of the forces at play.

It is sponsored by a flat Earth research group, and Hughes plans a subsequent trip to try and observe the flatness of the Earth for himself. Speaking about the risks of the flight, Hughes said: “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.” Hughes’ website describes him as “the only man to design, build and launch himself in a rocket” – he previously flew in his own rocket in 2014, as this footage shows. Hughes has stated that once he lands at the weekend, he intends to announce that he is running for the governorship of California.

-------
 Science is littered with tales of visionaries who paid for pioneering research to prove their theories, and this weekend “Mad” Mike Hughes is hoping to join them. He plans to launch a homemade rocket in California as part of a bid to eventually prove that the Earth is flat. Hughes has spent $20,000 (£15,000) building the steam-powered rocket in his spare time, and will be livestreaming the launch over the internet. The self-described daredevil says he switched his focus to rockets after twice breaking his back doing stunt jumps in cars. “I don’t believe in science,” declared the 61-year-old. “I know about aerodynamics and fluid dynamics and how things move through the air. But that’s not science, that’s just a formula.” The rocket, which Hughes aims to reach an altitude of 1,800ft (550 metres) over California, will be launched from the back of a converted motorhome purchased from Craigslist. It is sponsored by a flat Earth research group, and Hughes plans a subsequent trip to try and observe the flatness of the Earth for himself. Speaking about the risks of the flight, Hughes said: “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.” Hughes’ website describes him as “the only man to design, build and launch himself in a rocket” – he previously flew in his own rocket in 2014, as this footage shows. Hughes has stated that once he lands at the weekend, he intends to announce that he is running for the governorship of California.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks. Your answer must contain exactly 5 bullet points. Use the markdown bullet points such as:
* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2 There should be 2 paragraphs. Paragraphs are separated with the markdown divider: *** At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.S.
response:
"  
* Mike Hughes, a 61-year-old self-described daredevil and flat-Earther, is set to launch a homemade steam-powered rocket from a converted motorhome in California. The rocket is designed to reach an altitude of 1,800 feet and prove the Earth is flat, a mission Hughes believes in despite criticism from the scientific community.  
* Hughes, who has spent $20,000 and countless hours building the rocket, plans to livestream the launch on social media platforms. He has already gained sponsorship from a flat Earth research group and aims to observe the Earth’s flatness firsthand after the flight.  
***  
* The rocket, named after Hughes’ late father, will be launched from the back of a motorhome purchased for $7,000 on Craigslist. Hughes has undergone rigorous testing and certification from aviation authorities, though he remains confident in his unconventional design.  
* Once the rocket lands, Hughes plans to announce his candidacy for governor of California, leveraging his rocket launch as a campaign boost. He hopes the event will rally support for his anti-science, flat-earth agenda.  
* Despite the dangers—Hughes acknowledges the risks but remains Optimistic— he is determined to proceed, stating, “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.”  
***  
* The event has sparked worldwide attention, with critics arguing that Hughes’ efforts are not only risky but also scientifically baseless. Yet, Hughes’ unwavering belief in his cause and his boldness in pursuing it make him a figure of both admiration and controversy.  
P.S."
reasoning:
Alright, I need to help the user by generating a story based on the provided news article. The key is to use the 5 bullet points as requested, each in separate paragraphs separated by a divider. Plus, a P.S. at the end.

First, I'll read through the provided text to understand the main points. Mike Hughes is a 61-year-old daredevil planning to launch a steam-powered rocket to prove the Earth is flat. He's spent $20,000, using a converted motorhome as a launchpad. He's livestreaming the event, and after the flight, he plans to run for governor.

So, the first bullet point should cover his background and mission. Next, the rocket's specifications and method of launch. Then, the certification process from the aviation authorities. After that, his post-flight plans, including the gubernatorial announcement. Finally, the risks he's acknowledging but proceeding with despite them.

I should ensure each bullet is concise and captures the essence of each part. Also, make sure to wrap the entire response in quotes and use the P.S. as instructed. No markdown, just plain text within the quotes.

Let me structure this step by step, making sure each bullet is a separate paragraph. I'll avoid any extra information not covered in the original text and keep each point clear and to the point. After drafting, I'll review to ensure everything is covered and the response meets all the user's requirements.

"  
* Mike Hughes, a 61-year-old self-described daredevil and flat-Earther, is set to launch a homemade steam-powered rocket from a converted motorhome in California. The rocket is designed to reach an altitude of 1,800 feet and prove the Earth is flat, a mission Hughes believes in despite criticism from the scientific community.  
* Hughes, who has spent $20,000 and countless hours building the rocket, plans to livestream the launch on social media platforms. He has already gained sponsorship from a flat Earth research group and aims to observe the Earth’s flatness firsthand after the flight.  
***  
* The rocket, named after Hughes’ late father, will be launched from the back of a motorhome purchased for $7,000 on Craigslist. Hughes has undergone rigorous testing and certification from aviation authorities, though he remains confident in his unconventional design.  
* Once the rocket lands, Hughes plans to announce his candidacy for governor of California, leveraging his rocket launch as a campaign boost. He hopes the event will rally support for his anti-science, flat-earth agenda.  
* Despite the dangers—Hughes acknowledges the risks but remains Optimistic— he is determined to proceed, stating, “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.”  
***  
* The event has sparked worldwide attention, with critics arguing that Hughes’ efforts are not only risky but also scientifically baseless. Yet, Hughes’ unwavering belief in his cause and his boldness in pursuing it make him a figure of both admiration and controversy.  
P.S."

-------
 Surging levels of violence at an “unsafe” G4S-run youth jail have put staff in hospital and caused inmates to carry improvised weapons for their safety, inspectors have revealed. The damning inspection report into Oakhill secure training centre, near Milton Keynes, was published on Tuesday as MPs heard that ministers had ordered G4S to set up an external inquiry into abuse allegations at Brook House, the immigration removal centre at Gatwick, which is also run by the private security firm. The joint report by the prison inspectors, with Ofsted and the Care Quality Commission, into Oakhill in September and October – when the centre was near capacity, with 75 boys aged 14 to 17 – finds “no evidence that staff can adequately care and control this volume of young people”. The report rates the youth prison as “inadequate” and says there has been an increase in fights and assaults since the last inspection in January; it records 330 assaults between March and August this year alone, with assaults against staff increasing, including against newly recruited staff, and some so serious they have led to people being taken to hospital. “One manager said that young people are carrying improvised weapons because they do not feel safe. This inhibits some staff from intervening because of the fear of a weapon, and this in turn reinforces the view of young people that staff cannot protect them, thereby continuing the cycle,” the report says. The inspectors say that many of the recommendations from their January inspection have not been met and the centre has deteriorated in most respects, including to do with safety, care, education, resettlement and the “effectiveness of leaders and managers”. They say that unacceptable behaviour, including swearing, intimidation and vandalism, is not being challenged by staff. Oakhill’s newly appointed interim director, Lisette Saunders, said: “We take these findings very seriously. In the report Ofsted recognised that senior managers at Oakhill know what is required to bring the centre up to acceptable standards.

A G4S-run youth jail near Milton Keynes has come under fire after inspectors uncovered alarming levels of violence and poor management, leaving staff hospitalized and inmates carrying improvised weapons for safety. The Oakhill secure training centre, inspected by prison inspectors, Ofsted, and the Care Quality Commission, was found to be “inadequate” and plagued by fights, assaults, and a lack of control over the young inmates.  

The report, published on Tuesday, revealed that 330 assaults occurred between March and August this year, with staff increasingly targeted, including newly recruited workers. Some incidents were so severe that they required hospitalization. One manager highlighted that young people are carrying improvised weapons due to feelings of insecurity, creating a cycle of fear among staff and residents.  

The inspectors noted that many previous recommendations from a January inspection had not been implemented, and the centre had deteriorated in key areas like safety, care, education, and leadership. Unacceptable behavior, such as swearing, intimidation, and vandalism, goes unchecked, with staff failing to challenge such actions effectively.  

Lisette Saunders, Oakhill’s newly appointed interim director, acknowledged the findings and stated that senior managers are aware of the need to bring the centre up to acceptable standards. However, the report paints a grim picture of a facility that is failing to provide a safe and supportive environment for its young inmates.  

Any other questions?

 The world is changing as new technologies rip through old economies. The prospect of life outside the European Union will alter how we trade, move goods and people around and make our way in the world. For a long time these questions about the future have been neglected by national governments – left to the market, to globalisation, to Brussels. Now we need active change. To provide it, the government is launching its industrial strategy white paper, which will be published next Monday and heavily trailed during this week’s budget. In a welcome move, Theresa May has already outlined how the government plans to increase public and private R&D investment by up to £80bn over the next 10 years. The prime minister also announced £1.7bn to improve transport links within city regions. This comes as the UK is in serious need of new thinking to address fundamental long-term economic challenges: poor productivity, unbalanced regional growth and a weak track record in translating knowledge creation into inclusive wealth creation. The impact of the financial collapse in 2008 and the recent decision to leave the EU have only exacerbated these deep-seated national problems. A long-term industrial strategy for the UK that includes proper investment in R&D and connectivity is overdue.
-------

Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Answer with less than 241 words. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
The compilation, a survey of emerging British talent, touted as "alt-folk," delivering a mix of gentle singer-songwriters and experimental folk. While the label promised a wild, unconventional sound, the tracks leaned toward conventional chamber folk, with shy, introspective lyrics and crisp, acoustic arrangements. Yet, the collection wasn’t without its flashes of brilliance. Brooke Sharkey’s airy, Anglo-French Chamber folk offered a haunting beauty, while Ferris and Sylvester’s dreamy pop-infused tracks carried a spiky, Simon and Garfunkel-esque charm. Seven-piece Mishaped Pearls stood out with their cinematic six-piece "Six Dukes," weaving a tale of grandeur and loneliness.

The album served as a rewarding snapshot of a vibrant live scene, all while operating as a not-for-profit project, bridging artists and audiences. Yet, it couldn’t escape the shadow of its misleading moniker, leaving listeners questioning the true nature of its sound. P.P.S. The collection underscored the complexity of categorization, hinting at a deeper, more nuanced exploration of folk’s evolving forms.

(Just over 240 words)

In 2010, it was reported that tapes had been submitted to the courts of Gibson allegedly using racist language and threatening to kill Grigorieva. He is also alleged to have said she deserved a beating. In one of the most notorious incidents involving the actor and director, Gibson unleashed an antisemitic rant in 2006 against a police officer in Malibu, California, who had pulled him over for drunk driving. He accused Jews of being responsible for “all the wars in the world”. He was convicted of driving under the influence. His latest comments come after dozens of women alleged they had been sexually harassed or assaulted by Weinstein.

 Theresa May would need to secure a clear Brexit transition agreement by March if she wanted to avoid a “snowballing” number of companies activating contingency plans and even moving operations out of the UK, the Institute of Directors will warn. Stephen Martin, director general of the business group, is to issue the ultimatum to the government at the IoD annual dinner on Tuesday, saying “all we want for Christmas is progress on Brexit”. He will say the time would come soon when the IoD may have to advise all of its members to be ready for no deal and urged the government to stop this outcome. “We know from our recent surveys that over half of you are already in the process of contingency planning,” Martin will say. “The number of businesses who have actually implemented these plans is currently low, around one in 10, but this will snowball if we don’t find out soon what is going to happen in March 2019. “It’s clear that the government has a small window of opportunity between now and the end of the first quarter of next year to secure a firm political agreement on transition. If we don’t have this commitment by the end of March, then business will come under pressure to implement contingency plans, even perhaps as far as relocating operations.” He will say companies supported the idea of a transitional period after March 2019 to help the UK and rest of the EU adjust to Brexit, but they needed to know that cross-border trade would effectively remain unchanged. Martin will say that businesses do not want to move to World Trade Organisation rules as it would be a “huge drop down from where we are now” but may soon have to start planning for that possibility. “WTO is not the simple option, it would involve massive complexity to adjust our customs procedures, and we would lose not just our level of access to the single market, but also potentially all of the trade and investment agreements we have with other countries through the EU,” he will say. “It’s not desirable, but it is possible.

What to look out for: The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) is expected to downgrade the 2% GDP growth it was expecting for 2017 back in March to about 1.5%. response:
In the quiet corridors of power, Philip Hammond, the UK’s Chancellor, stood before a daunting array of challenges. His first budget statement since the general election was not just a financial plan but a existential test of his leadership. The coordinating act of his career, he knew, would determine whether he could steer the UK economy back on course. But as he gazed at the spreadsheets and reports, a distant bell tolled. The bell was not a warning but a reminder: the UK had avoided recession, but its economy was still teetering on the edge. The anticipated growth had stalled, and the structural issues plaguing public services, welfare, and housing loomed larger than ever.

Hammond shifted in his seat, his mind racing. He had faced setbacks before—most notably when his plan to increase national insurance on the self-employed had been met with a fierce backlash from his own party. That humiliating u-turn had exposed his political vulnerability, a fact that had been compounded by the June election. The bell had been struck once more, and this time, the echoes were louder. The UK’s economic outlook was dim, and Hammond knew he had to act. The meat of his plans, he understood, lay not just in numbers but in the real, tangible impact on people’s lives.

aciculation of muscle, of decisive action, was required. Hammond’s advisers had urged him to focus on productivity, yet the numbers painted a bleak picture. The UK’s GDP growth had slowed to 1.7% in 2016, with the first half of 2017 showing a meager 0.5% increase. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) had already downgraded its growth forecast for the year, and further downgrades were expected. The bell was now sounding consistently, a relentless reminder of the fragile state of the economy.

Yet, amidst the turmoil, Hammond saw an opportunity. He knew that education was not just a catchphrase but a critical component of the nation’s recovery. Investing in young people, in their futures, could bridge the gap left by years of stagnation. But as he considered the housing market, which had effectively locked a generation out of home ownership, he realized the depth of the challenge. The meat of his plans, he understood, must address not just punitive economic policies but systemic issues that had been neglected for years.

Hammond rose from his desk, the weight of the decision pressing heavily on his shoulders. His mind wandered to a painting he had once seen—a bold, vibrant canvas that depicted the rise of a nation. The painting’s strokes, bold and unflinching, represented the vision he held for the UK’s future—a vision of renewal and resilience. He knew that the path ahead would be fraught with obstacles, but he also understood that leadership required strength, clarity, and the courage to face the bell. The bell would not be silenced easily, but with each step forward, he believed, dawn was still possible.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.

 An appeal against a ban on Silvio Berlusconi holding public office is to be heard by the European court of human rights, in a move that could potentially see Italy’s scandal-tainted former prime minister leading the country again. The hearing on Wednesday, six years after he was forced from office, follows his success at forging a winning coalition out of his centre-right Forza Italia and two far-right parties – the Northern League and Brothers of Italy – in regional elections in Sicily earlier this month. The outcome of the ballot on the southern Italian island was largely seen as a rehearsal for how things might play out in national elections, which must be held before May next year. It also marked the beginning of an authentic political comeback for the 81-year-old, despite being plagued by a tax fraud conviction, sex scandals and allegations of corruption. Considering the length of time it takes for the court to deliver a verdict, it is unlikely to come before the general elections. The current five-year term for the Italian government officially expires on 15 March, although the vote could be held as late as May. “I hope that the Strasbourg court will accept my appeal,” Berlusconi wrote on Twitter on Wednesday. “But my role in the next electoral campaign is clear regardless: I will be in the field looking to take the centre-right into government.” The billionaire, who was forced to resign from his third term as prime minister in 2011 over claims he paid for sex with an underage sex worker, has hired top lawyers from London’s Doughty Street Chambers to fight his case. He was ejected from parliament and banned from running for office for six years in 2013 due to his tax fraud conviction. “We’ll have just 30 minutes to set out our argument, the same goes for the government,” Andrea Saccucci, one of the lawyers who will represent Berlusconi in the Strasbourg court, told the Guardian.
-------

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The UK, even today, is not well blessed with festivals devoted to new music. But when the Huddersfield contemporary music festival began, in 1978, the situation was much worse, with no annual showcase here for what living composers were producing. That such an event took root in an unprepossessing West Yorkshire industrial town in the late 70s was remarkable in itself, especially when most of the activity in new music then was centred on London. What began on a modest scale under the aegis of Huddersfield Polytechnic (now the University of Huddersfield) – where the festival’s tireless founding director, Richard Steinitz, was a lecturer in music – grew quickly into one of the most important dates in the British musical calendar. The HCMF really hit its stride in the early 80s, hosting a series of important premieres alongside residencies from many of the senior figures of postwar music, from Olivier Messiaen and Terry Riley to Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter. Gradually expanding its ambition and range, Steinitz’s programming was never narrowly doctrinal; from the early days, he tried to reflect the spectrum of what was going on across Europe and the US. Steinitz stood down as director after the 2000 festival. The current director, Graham McKenzie, has been there for more than a decade, not only steering the programming towards new generations of composers from across Europe, but also broadening the stylistic scope, including events that touch on jazz, electronica and rock. With these changes, so the atmosphere of the festival has altered. This is partly because the generation of postwar composers whose appearances made the early festivals so memorable has all but gone, but also because, in those days, festival audiences had a sense of a shared purpose.
-------
