response:
The Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival, or HCMF, began its journey in 1978 as a modest endeavor to showcase new music in a West Yorkshire industrial town. At the time, the UK lacked a significant festival dedicated to contemporary composers, and Huddersfield, despite its unassuming appearance, became an unlikely hub for creative expression. The festival was founded by Richard Steinitz, a tireless lecturer at Huddersfield Polytechnic (now the University of Huddersfield), who envisioned it as a space for exploration and innovation in music.

In the early days, the festival was a bulwark against the stylistic uniformity that dominated theUK music scene. Steinitz’s programming was broad, never confined to a single doctrine, but rather a reflection of the dynamic landscape of European and American music. The festival quickly grew, thanks in part to its ability to attract senior figures in postwar music, such as Olivier Messiaen, Terry Riley, Hans Werner Henze, and Elliott Carter. These composers brought with them a wealth of experience and a willingness to engage with the young audience that flocked to Huddersfield.

Over the decades, the festival evolved. Richard Steinitz, who had shepherded the event through its formative years, stepped down in 2000, leaving Graham McKenzie to take the reins. McKenzie brought with him a fresh perspective, steering the festival toward new generations of composers from across Europe. He also broadened the stylistic scope, incorporating jazz, electronica, and even rock into the lineup. These changes were met with both excitement and concern by long-time attendees, who witnessed the gradual exit of the postwar generation and the rise of a younger, more diverse audience.

Despite these shifts, the festival remained a beacon of creativity. The audiences, though smaller and more dispersed, brought with them a patience born of years of dedication. They were no longer united by a single purpose, as they had been in the festival’s earliest days, but instead embracing a broader spectrum of musical exploration.

The team behind the festival worked tirelessly to curate a lineup that challenged traditional boundaries, often causing the audience to tap into unfamiliar sounds and rhythms. The atmosphere of the festival was no longer the stuffy, suited affairs of old but a more relaxed, inclusive celebration of music in all its forms. Even as the storm of change swept through the UK’s cultural landscape, HCMF remained a locus of collaboration and innovation.

Today, the festival is a testament to the power of persistence and adaptability. It continues to bring together a bunch of dedicated musicians, composers, and audiences, each tapping into the shared experience of contemporary music. As the festival looks to the future, it does so with a renewed sense of energy and a commitment to pushing the boundaries of sound and expression.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Concordia International, the Canadian drug company, has overcharged the NHS by more than £100m in the past decade for a life-changing thyroid drug, according to Britain’s competition watchdog. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had provisionally found that Concordia had “abused its dominant position to overcharge the NHS” by hiking the price of liothyronine, used to treat patients with an underactive thyroid, by nearly 6,000% between 2007 and 2017. The regulator said the NHS had spent more than £34m on the drug last year, up from about £600,000 in 2006. The amount it paid per pack rose from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by July 2017. Concordia could be fined up to 10% of its worldwide annual turnover. Liothyronine tablets are used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition caused by a deficiency of the thyroid hormone that affects at least two in 100 people and can lead to depression, tiredness and weight gain. For many patients there is no alternative and, until this year, Concordia was the only supplier. This summer, the UK firm Morningside Healthcare and Israel’s Teva were granted licences to supply the drug. The medicine, a synthetic version of the hormone T3, is taken by patients who do not respond well to the cheaper alternative, levothyroxine.

response:
"Concordia International, a Canadian pharmaceutical company, has been accused by Britain’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) of overcharging the National Health Service (NHS) by more than £100 million over a decade for a life-changing thyroid drug. The regulator revealed that Concordia ‘abused its dominant position to overcharge the NHS’ by significantly increasing the price of liothyronine, a drug used to treat hypothyroidism, between 2007 and 2017. The price of the drug soared by nearly 6,000%, with the NHS spending over £34 million on it in 2017, up from about £600,000 in 2006. The cost per pack rose from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by July 2017, while the price of a single pill increased from 16p to £9.22. Despite production costs remaining stable during this period, the excessive pricing has drawn sharp criticism from health officials and patient advocates.

Strategy The CMA’s Provisional Findings: The Competition and Markets Authority has provisionally concluded that Concordia’s behavior constitutes an abuse of market dominance, potentially leading to significant financial penalties. The regulator has emphasized that the company’sogra decade-long price hikes were unjustified, given that production costs remained unchanged. Concordia could face fines up to 10% of its global annual turnover, which could amount to a substantial sum given the company’s revenue. The CMA has called for further investigation into whether other suppliers could have offered a cheaper alternative, potentially reducing the financial burden on the NHS.

The Implications for the NHS and Patients: The overcharging has had profound implications for the NHS, which is already strained by limited budgets. The sharp rise in liothyronine’s cost has made it harder for healthcare providers to allocate resources efficiently. For many patients, the drug is a critical lifeline, as it is the only treatment effective for those who do not respond to the cheaper alternative, levothyroxine. Hypothyroidism, a condition affecting at least two in 100 people, can lead to serious health complications, including depression, fatigue, and weight gain. Without access to affordable treatment, many patients may face prolonged suffering or even life-threatening conditions.

New Competition on the Horizon: This summer, the UK-based company Morningside Healthcare and Israel’s Teva were granted licenses to supply liothyronine, marking the end of Concordia’s monopoly. This new competition could help bring down prices, offering a much-needed relief to the NHS and patients. However, the transition to new suppliers may present challenges, as the NHS must navigate the complexities of switching suppliers and ensuring the continued availability of the drug. The arrival of alternative suppliers also raises hopes that the market will become more competitive, potentially leading to permanent price reductions. For now, though, the focus remains on addressing the excessive pricing by Concordia and ensuring that patients have access to the treatment they depend on."

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Turnbull government has deployed new modelling on the national energy guarantee in an effort to step up pressure on state governments to sign up to its policy at a meeting of energy ministers on Friday. A summary of the modelling, circulated by the government in advance of the talks with the states, suggests household power bills between 2020 and 2030 would be “in the order of” $120 a year lower, in today’s dollars, than under a business-as-usual scenario, if the policy applied across the national electricity market. The material supplied by the government says wholesale electricity prices would be 23% lower than business-as-usual between 2020 and 2030, and it suggests the share of renewables in the market by 2030 “could range from 32% to 36%”. The full modelling, undertaken for the Energy Security Board by Frontier Economics, has not yet been distributed to state energy ministers and the documents circulated in Canberra are a summary of the findings, not the work itself. The Turnbull government announced in October it would dump the clean energy target recommended by the chief scientist, Alan Finkel, and proceed with the national energy guarantee – a policy that imposes new reliability and emissions reduction guarantees on energy retailers and large energy users from 2020. The policy requires cooperation from the states but some of the Labor governments, particularly South Australia, have been hostile. Part of the reason for that is the states were involved in the exhaustive consultations with Finkel about the clean energy target but were not kept in the loop about the national energy guarantee. Some state governments are also concerned the Turnbull policy will hard-bake coal into the system at the expense of renewables at a time when the energy market needs to transition to low-emissions power sources. A spokesman for the South Australian premier, Jay Weatherill, is continuing to insist that the state will not commit to sign on to the national energy guarantee in the absence of data showing its specific impact on the state. The Labor states have also commissioned their own work through the Council of Australian Governments energy council examining whether or not they could implement a clean energy target by themselves.
-------

Walkinshaw was well over the limit, returning a reading of 0.149.

 The Czech tennis player Jana Novotná, who has died of cancer aged 49, had a career of consistent success that would have more than satisfied most players, but fell some way short of what she would have achieved had she possessed a much steadier nerve. In 1998, the year before she retired, Novotná became only the fifth female player to pass the $10m mark in career prize money and in the same year was within reach of being ranked No 1 in the world. As an athlete she was among the best of her era, possessed of consummate skill in the dying and difficult art of serve-and-volley and an ability to deliver a backhand smash that was the envy of her peers. And yet in her 14 years at the top of the women’s game she won only 24 tour singles titles. Even more disappointingly, she reached the last eight in 22 of the 50 grand slam singles events in which she competed but managed to convert that consistency into just one title. The American player and commentator Pam Shriver, who was a good friend, explained this by saying that Novotná was “as kind as she was athletic”. Others, mostly tennis writers such as myself, put it more brutally: she was a choker. Novotná herself said she hated the idea of choking, preferring instead to say that she “got a little tight”. Her most famous episode of getting a little tight is now a case study for sports psychologists. It came in the 1993 Wimbledon final when she led Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and at 40-30 in the sixth game of the deciding set had a service point for a 5-1 lead over the German.
-------

Despite her unfulfilled potential, Novotná’s legacy is undiminished. She was a trailblazer for women’s tennis, paving the way for future generations with her skill, grace, and determination. Jana Novotná’s death at the age of 49 marked the end of an era, but her impact on the game endures. turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 EasyJet saw its profits fall 17% last year, with more than £100m lost due to the slump in the pound after the Brexit vote. The airline reported a record year for passenger numbers, flying 80.2 million people, almost 10% more than in 2015-16, on ever fuller planes. But while revenues exceeded £5bn in 2016-17, fares dipped to fill seats in what the chief executive, Carolyn McCall, said was “a difficult year for the aviation industry”. McCall said: “Our planned approach of achieving number one or two positions at Europe’s leading airports, friendly and efficient customer service and a continuous focus on sustainable cost control, has put easyJet at a strategic advantage during a period when there have been bankruptcies and some airlines have struggled operationally.” Profits before tax fell from £494m to £408m. Despite paying a lower dollar price for fuel, the continued weakness of sterling brought additional costs of £101m, easyJet said. The airline will also be prompted by Brexit to change its rules to ensure easyJet is majority owned and controlled by EU nationals after 2019. About a third of shares are owned by the easyJet founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who has dual UK-Cypriot nationality, and will be classed as EU-owned. But easyJet will ask at its 2018 AGM for new powers to force UK shareholders to sell up if necessary to allow it to continue operating in Europe. McCall said the move was “a technical, administrative thing” and the airline had “no concerns” about getting enough EU shareholders. Shares rose by more than 5% in early trading, on the back of the airline reporting high levels of forward bookings and better revenue so far in its 2017-18 financial year, which it said was “primarily as a result of some capacity leaving the market”.
-------

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.

 There are three broad categories of microbiome, named by Atlas, a company that will analyse the bacterial environment in your gut: the Urban Citizen, the Village Peasant and the Indigene. Your type can change if you significantly alter your diet. Anyone with any sense wants to be an Indigene, since the Urban Citizen is associated with the “western diet” (code for: “some Cinnamon Grahams and a KFC, what of it?”) and the Village Peasant sounds a bit, you know, dumpy. However, the Indigene is most prevalent in isolated tribespeople from the Amazon and Africa, or failing that, vegetarians. I got my results back from the £125 test I did in August, a complicated business of trapping poo on a piece of paper. I did this because your gut environment is as vital to your overall health as your hormonal one, or your brain chemistry; its health is determined by bacterial balance, which in turn is affected by your diet. I’m a Village Peasant. It turns out, now that I am one, they’re the best. I have bacteria from the Dorea genus to reduce inflammation of the gut, making it less likely that I’ll get Crohn’s disease. I have eubacterium, built by bananas and barley which, since I hate bananas, I can only ascribe to my high consumption of Ovaltine.
-------

I did this because your gut environment is as vital to your overall health as your hormonal one, or your brain chemistry; its health is determined by bacterial balance, which in turn is affected by your diet. I’m a Village Peasant. It turns out, now that I am one, they’re the best. I have bacteria from the Dorea genus to reduce inflammation of the gut, making it less likely that I’ll get Crohn’s disease. I have eubacterium, built by bananas and barley which, since I hate bananas, I can only ascribe to my high consumption of Ovaltine.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The campaign group that encouraged Paperchase to apologise for its marketing activities with the Daily Mail is pushing for John Lewis, the department store chain, to stop advertising with the newspaper as well as with the Sun and Daily Express. John Lewis has become a prime target for Stop Funding Hate on the back of the launch of its Christmas advert and as retailers increase their spending on advertising as the festive season approaches. Stop Funding Hate has produced a mock advert that depicts the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert – Buster the dog – as unhappy because the retailer is buying adverts with the Mail, Sun, and Express. The video has been shared almost 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate. The organisation was founded last year and says its aim is to take on “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun and Express, and persuade advertisers to cease their financial input. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, said: “[John Lewis] are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for. Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, John Lewis said it would continue advertising with the newspapers and not bow to the pressure. A spokesperson said: “Withdrawing advertising on the basis of editorial coverage would be inconsistent with our democratic principles, which include freedom of speech and remaining apolitical.” Paperchase announced on Monday that it would not run any marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail and said it was “truly sorry” for running a front-page promotion in Saturday’s edition of the newspaper.
-------

response:
Classic campaigns for social and ethical change often hinge on a mix of public sentiment and corporate principle, and the latest movement targeting John Lewis’s advertising partnerships with The Daily Mail, The Sun, and The Daily Express is no exception. Stop Funding Hate, the grassroots campaign behind the push, has gained momentum in recent weeks, amplifying its message through a unsettling yet impactful mock Christmas advert featuring Buster the dog, the star of last year’s John Lewis ad. The video, which depicts Buster as unhappy and dissociated from his festive joy, has been shared nearly 10,000 times across Twitter and Facebook, sparking a broader debate about the role of media in spreading divisiveness.

John Lewis, a retailer long celebrated for its ethical values and customer loyalty, has found itself at the center of this controversy. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, praised the company’s ethical standing but expressed disappointment with its decision to continue advertising with the newspapers. “John Lewis are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for,” Wilson said. “Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, the retailer has thus far resisted the pressure, with a spokesperson emphasizing its commitment to democratic principles, including freedom of speech and apoliticism in its advertising choices.

While John Lewis remains defiant, the campaign’s impact is undeniable. Stop Funding Hate has also targeted other major retail brands, including Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer, and Waitrose, engulfing the festive season in a swirl of activism. The group, founded just last year, aims to hold media outlets accountable for what it deems divisive hate campaigns and persuade advertisers to sever ties. Meanwhile, Paperchase, which recently announced it would cease its marketing partnership with The Daily Mail, has become a symbol of change, offering a swift apology and a shift in strategy. As the debate rages on, the challenge for companies like John Lewis lies not just in aligning their values with their advertising choices but in navigating the broader cultural and political implications of their decisions. This festive season, the fight over free speech and ethical responsibility may be as much about the power of aoteria as it is about the power of a dog named Buster.

John Lewis, a retailer long celebrated for its ethical values and customer loyalty, has found itself at the center of this controversy. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, praised the company’s ethical standing but expressed disappointment with its decision to continue advertising with the newspapers. “John Lewis are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for,” Wilson said. “Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, the retailer has thus far resisted the pressure, with a spokesperson emphasizing its commitment to democratic principles, including freedom of speech and apoliticism in its advertising choices.

While John Lewis remains defiant, the campaign’s impact is undeniable. Stop Funding Hate has also targeted other major retail brands, including Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer, and Waitrose, engulfing the festive season in a swirl of activism. The group, founded just last year, aims to hold media outlets accountable for what it deems divisive hate campaigns and persuade advertisers to sever ties. Meanwhile, Paperchase, which recently announced it would cease its marketing partnership with The Daily Mail, has become a symbol of change, offering a swift apology and a shift in strategy. As the debate rages on, the challenge for companies like John Lewis lies not just in aligning their values with their advertising choices but in navigating the broader cultural and political implications of their decisions. This festive season, the fight over free speech and ethical responsibility may be as much about the power of aoteria as it is about the power of a dog named Buster.
